js-fn-01.explanation: In JavaScript, functions are first-class objects but `typeof` returns `function`.
js-fn-01.interviewTip: Mention that functions are callable objects with internal [[Call]].

js-fn-02.explanation: Function declarations are hoisted with their body.

js-fn-03.explanation: `bar` exists but is undefined at call time.
js-fn-03.interviewTip: Function expressions are not hoisted like declarations.

js-fn-04.explanation: Parentheses allow implicit return of an object.

js-fn-05.prompt: Arrow functions differ from regular functions because they…
js-fn-05.explanation: Arrow functions capture `this` from lexical scope.
js-fn-05.interviewTip: Great question to test understanding of `this`.

js-fn-06.interviewTip: Mention that arrow functions don’t have `arguments`.

js-fn-07.explanation: Default parameters apply when argument is `undefined`.

js-fn-08.explanation: Automatic semicolon insertion ends the return.

js-fn-09.explanation: Higher-order functions operate on other functions.

js-fn-13.explanation: Arrow functions cannot be used as constructors.

js-fn-19.explanation: Tail call optimization can reuse stack.
js-fn-19.interviewTip: Not widely optimized in JS engines.

js-fn-20.explanation: Default params can reference previous params.

js-fn-21.prompt: What happens if a function has no return?

js-fn-25.prompt: Why are functions called first-class citizens?
